Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SusChEM: Perfluoroether-based Polymer Electrolytes for Lithium Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitash Balsara / Joseph DeSimone
1505669 / 1510579

Although electric and hybrid vehicles have the potential to reduce dependence on fossil fuels for transportation, the rechargeable lithium batteries that currently power them suffer from many problems. Current designs can hold 10% of their theoretical amount of energy content, contain highly flammable organic liquid electrolytes, are relatively costly, and do not last as long as a typical automobile. New battery materials are needed to address these problems. The objective of this project is to develop high-performance electrolytes for lithium batteries that have no flammable components, potentially leading to improved safety. These electrolytes will be based on nonflammable fluorinated polymers designed to dissolve lithium ions and maintain high ion conductivity for improved charging and discharging rates. The proposed research will make and test these new polymer materials for battery applications, and try to understand the fundamental science underlying their performance. The proposed educational activities associated with this project include an engineering summer camp for underserved high school students in the Oakland-Berkeley area that features hands-on projects related to lithium batteries.


The overall goal of the proposed research is to develop perfluoropolyether (PFPE)-based electrolytes for lithium batteries. It is believed that this material is a promising new electrolyte for two principal reasons. First, PFPE materials are a class of fluoropolymers that are intrinsically nonflammable and exhibit low vapor pressure as well as thermal, chemical and oxidative stability. Second, for lithium ion battery applications, PFPE-based electrolytes also can dissolve lithium salts with fluoridated anions. This electrolyte system possesses high conductivity dominated by molecular lithium ion (Li+) transport, owing to the low glass transition temperature of the PFPE materials, and the solvation of fluorinated anions by fluorinated polymers, which immobilizes the anion on the polymer. The proposed research will synthesize functionalized homo- and block co-polymer perfluoropolyethers and lithium salts, characterize the electrochemical properties of these electrolytes, and assess their ion transport and cycling performance in electrochemical energy storage test devices. Selected research outcomes will be used to support the development of a start-up company and provide entrepreneurial training for students involved on the project. Additional education and outreach activities are also planned in coordination with the Professional Development Program at UC Berkeley and with the Research Triangle Electrochemical Society Student Chapter.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Addressing the safety of the lithium ion batteries in use every day is a very important area of research.  Developing safer batteries by removing the volatile constituents and safely ensconcing the highly reactive lithium inside an inert, temperature stable electrolyte, is critical to developing high functioning safer batteries. Our NSF supported research on developing non-flammable lithium ion battery electrolytes based on perfluoropolyethers (PFPE)s has been conducted in close collaboration with the Balsara group at UC Berkeley. Cross institutional collaboration has allowed us to have a stronger program as we can leverage resources and technical input from both universities. Regular conference calls to discuss results, transferred materials, data sharing, and co-authored publications have resulted. We have supported and trained two graduate students and two post-doctoral researchers at UNC as a result of completing this project award.

Through the support of this award we have identified both advantages and disadvantages of applying lithium salt loaded PFPEs as electrolytes for lithium ion batteries. Our fundamental understanding of the science of lithium ion transport in PFPEs was moved forward significantly as a result of this NSF funded program. PFPEs are non-flammable polymeric liquids at room temperature that are capable of dissolving fluorinated lithium salts typically used in commercial lithium ion batteries. We produced and characterized a variety of different PFPE based materials and provided many of the promising materials to our collaborators at UC Berkeley for inclusion in battery test cells. The results indicate that we can affect how different salts interact with the PFPE based based on both salt and PFPE structure, the lithium salts do not dissociate as readily in PFPEs as in commercial electrolyte solvents and this negatively impacts their ability to conduct electrons and generate power effectively. 

The DeSimone group encourages and enables undergraduate research in our science laboratories. We work with the Chancellor’s Science Scholars (CSS) program at UNC (http://chancellorssciencescholars.web.unc.edu/) and present at least once per year to CSS applicants and participants. Our presentations are designed to excite young people about science and technology research by providing real world examples of research programs that are focused on relevant issues such as safer batteries (non-flammable battery electrolytes), new cancer treatments, or 3D printed drug delivery devices. Over the past four years during the course of our NSF program we have mentored at least 7 undergraduates in undergraduate research with at least four of them going on to pursue advanced degrees and most maintaining research on their projects for one year or more. Our undergraduate researchers education concentrations have been in chemistry, biomedical engineering, and computer science and have included both women and students of races that are under represented in STEM fields.
